Takes multiple values to represent movement between several places on the same day. * start date can use either of the following properties, depending on whether it is known precisely: ** [[Property:Has definite start date|Has definite start date]] (type: date; single value): if the location definitely started on this day. ** [[Property:Has earliest known date|Has earliest known date]] (type: date; single value): if the location is known to have started on or before this day. * end date can use either of the following properties, depending on whether it is known precisely: ** [[Property:Has definite end date|Has definite end date]] (type: date; single value): if the location definitely ended on this day. ** [[Property:Has latest known date|Has latest known date]] (type: date; single value): if the location is known to have ended on or after this day. * non-semantic field to cite sources using free wikitext.
=== Command relationship subobject ===
Uses [[Template:Command relationship subobject]].
Repeatable subtemplate that creates a subobject that represents command relationships between organizations. Parent is usually a Unit or Area; subordinate can be Unit, Area, or Address.
Adapted from Linking Experiences of WW1 template [http://collaborativecollections.org/WorldWarOne/Template:Infobox_command_structure Infobox command structure] which in turn was adapted from [[Wikipedia:Template:Infobox command structure]].
* [[Property:Is instance of|Is instance of]]: always automatically set to [[Command relationship]]. * [[Property:Has role|Has role]]: allows multiple values because a parish is often a civil and ecclesiastical parent of places within it, and because a military unit might have the same tactical and administrative parent. Available values listed in [[:Category:Command relationship types]]. * [[Property:Has subordinate|Has subordinate]] (type: page; single value): the subordinate organization in the relationship. Always automatically set to the page name of the entity whose page the subobject is embedded in. * [[Property:Has parent|Has parent]] (type: page; multiple values): the parent organization in the relationship. Allows multiple values because the same relationship type might apply to more than one entity at the same time. Some of these are not strictly parent-child relationships, for example [[Ancestor area]]. * start date can use either of the following properties, depending on whether it is known precisely: ** [[Property:Has definite start date|Has definite start date]] (type: date; single value): if the relationship definitely started on this day. ** [[Property:Has earliest known date|Has earliest known date]] (type: date; single value): if the relationship is known to have started on or before this day. * end date can use either of the following properties, depending on whether it is known precisely: ** [[Property:Has definite end date|Has definite end date]] (type: date; single value): if the relationship definitely ended on this day. ** [[Property:Has latest known date|Has latest known date]] (type: date; single value): if the relationship is known to have ended on or after this day. * non-semantic field to cite sources using free wikitext.
== Property hierarchies ==
This wiki does not use Semantic MediaWiki's built-in subproperty feature because this can make it difficult to display property values in query results where the query searches for the parent property but the values are assigned to one or more subproperties. Instead we represent a simple two-level hierarchy by assigning the same value to the parent and child property at the same time. This means that a query for the parent property can directly display the value.
In the following list, the values assigned to the second-level properties (which are usually displayed on an entity's page and entered through the relevant form) are also silently assigned to the first-level properties:
* [[Property:Relates to|Relates to]] ** [[Property:Addressed to|Addressed to]] ** [[Property:Created by|Created by]] ** [[Property:Has author|Has author]] ** [[Property:Has editor|Has editor]] ** [[Property:Mentions|Mentions]] ** [[Property:Possibly mentions|Possibly mentions]] ** [[Property:Printed by|Printed by]] ** [[Property:Published by|Published by]] ** [[Property:Signed by|Signed by]] ** [[Property:To be sold at|To be sold at]] ** [[Property:To be sold by|To be sold by]] * [[Property:Has earliest known date|Has earliest known date]] ** [[Property:Has definite start date|Has definite start date]] * [[Property:Has latest known date|Has latest known date]] ** [[Property:Has definite end date|Has definite end date]]
[[Category:Help pages]]

revision.comment: /* Entering dates in transcripts and free text */ changed XML tag to wiki template
revision.text:
This page is about how to enter dates in forms, and how this site deals with the different calendars used in the past.
For quick reference, values for most date fields in forms should be entered like this:
* YYYY-MM-DD JL * YYYY-MM-DD GR
JL stands for the Julian calendar and GR for the Gregorian calendar (see below for more explanation of this).
For example, this is the date of the battle of Edgehill in each calendar:
* 1642-10-23 JL * 1642-11-02 GR
== The Julian and Gregorian calendars ==
The Julian calendar was used in most of Europe from ancient Rome until the 16th century. It got increasingly out of sync with the solar year because it had too many leap years. In 1582, the Catholic Church introduced the Gregorian calendar, which corrected the error. The new calendar was soon adopted by Catholic countries, and by some parts of the Netherlands, even though they were protestant and had already declared independence from Spain. Many other protestant and Eastern Orthodox countries only changed much later.
Great Britain and Ireland changed from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar in 1752, so documents from the British Civil Wars usually have Julian dates.
In the 17th century, the difference between the two calendars was 10 days. For example, 10 October Julian was 20 October Gregorian. The difference increased to 11 days in 1700 and is now 13 days. But note that the transition from Julian to Gregorian only changed the number of the day, not the day of the week, which is the same in both calendars. For example, the battle of Edgehill was fought on 23 October 1642 Julian, which was 2 November Gregorian, but it was a Sunday in both calendars.
Letters sent from a place that used one calendar to a place that used the other sometimes have double dates such as 10/20 October. This isn't always the case but you can tell which calendar was used if it also gives the day of the week. For example, Sunday 23 October 1642 must be Julian because 23 October 1642 Gregorian was a Thursday.
[http://people.albion.edu/imacinnes/calendar//Welcome.html Ian's English Calendar] can calculate the day of the week. You can also use the date tag on this site to automatically convert between calendars and find the day of the week (see below for more details).
For more information about calendars, see these Wikipedia pages:
* [[Wikipedia:Julian calendar|Julian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:Gregorian calendar|Gregorian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:Adoption of the Gregorian calendar|Adoption of the Gregorian calendar]] * [[Wikipedia:List of adoption dates of the Gregorian calendar per country|List of adoption dates of the Gregorian calendar per country]]
'''WARNING:''' Wikidata can store both Julian and Gregorian dates, but data has often been entered with the wrong calendar, so don't trust it.
The Julian calendar is sometimes known as Old Style and the Gregorian calendar is sometimes known as New Style, but these terms can also refer to the start of the new year, which is a different problem. See the next section below.
== The Old Style and New Style new years ==
New Style new year means starting the official year on 1 January (New Style can also refer to the Gregorian calendar, which is a different thing: see section above).
In Great Britain and Ireland, the Old Style new year was on the 25 March ''after'' 1 January (other Old Style new years have been used in other places and times, but these don't affect this project).
* Scotland changed to the New Style new year in 1600, but kept the Julian calendar until 1752 * England and Ireland changed to the New Style new year in 1752, at the same time as changing to the Gregorian calendar
Before these dates, documents dated from 1 January to 24 March can be ambiguous. Although the official new year started on 25 March, many people treated 1 January as the new year. For example, George Thomason, who collected the Thomason tracts, often wrote the Old Style year onto pamphlets that were printed with New Style years.
Modern printed editions of manuscripts often disambiguate dates by giving a double year. For example, 1 March 1644/5 means 1644 Old Style (year starting 25 March) and 1645 New Style (year starting 1 January).
Secondary sources often treat the year as starting on 1 January, and have a note at the start to say which calendar and new year style they are using.
This site follows the practice of most secondary sources: we treat the year as starting on 1 January, but otherwise use the calendar used in the original source. This means that if documents were created in England or Ireland between 1 January and 24 March in any year before 1752, you will need to convert the year to New Style but you don't need to convert between Julian and Gregorian dates.
'''WARNING:''' some online resources don't take the Old Style new year into account. Parish registers at [https://www.familysearch.org/ FamilySearch] can be misdated.
== Entering dates in form fields ==
Semantic properties that have the type [[Special:Types/Date|date]] are entered through form fields. If the form field doesn't yet have a value, it will display the text YYYY-MM-DD JL as a hint. This text will disappear when you start typing in the field.
Values for date fields in forms should be entered like this:
* YYYY-MM-DD JL * YYYY-MM-DD GR
That means a 4 digit year number, a 2 digit month number, and a 2 digit day number followed by JL for the Julian calendar or GR for the Gregorian calendar (see above for more explanation of this). There must be hyphens between the numbers, and a single space before the calendar code.
For example, this is the date of the battle of Edgehill in each calendar:
* 1642-10-23 JL * 1642-11-02 GR
Always specify which calendar you are using to avoid ambiguity (Semantic MediaWiki will make assumptions about the most appropriate calendar if you don't specify, but it's best practice to always be explicit).
You can enter a date in either calendar. It will automatically be displayed on the page with both Julian and Gregorian dates, and the day of the week.
It's usually best to use the same calendar as the documents that you are entering data about or using as evidence. If the document gives a double date with both the Julian and Gregorian day, you can use either but '''do not''' enter both at the same time as it won't work.
All dates entered in these form fields, whether Julian or Gregorian, should use 1 January as the start of the new year. You might need to modernize the year if it's from 1 January to 24 March. Some sources, especially modern printed editions of manuscript sources, might give a double year, such as 1644/5. In these cases, always use the second year given.
=== Uncertain dates ===
Date properties can store incomplete dates. You can leave out the day or month if they can't be known. For example:
* 1642 JL * 1642-10 JL
You should still specify the calendar in the source that the date comes from, as the discrepancy between the Julian and Gregorian calendars means that the months and years don't quite match.
You must always specify a year. Dates where the month and day are known but not the year can't be stored as semantic data. In these cases, just leave the date field blank but mention the incomplete date in free text somewhere else on the page.
=== Multiple dates ===
Most date fields can only take one date. The only exception is the date of a combat event. This can take multiple dates separated by a semi-colon if the event went on for more than one day.
=== Years only ===
The only exceptions to this format are:
* an author's year of death * year of publication of a book or article * year of completion of a thesis
These only take a year number with a maximum of 4 digits. This is stored as a [[Special:Types/Number|number]], not a date.
== Entering dates in transcripts and free text ==
You can use the template <nowiki>{{date}}</nowiki> to mark up a date in transcribed text, or format a date in free text. This template formats the date displayed on the page but does not store the date as a semantic property. It's similar to the [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-date.html TEI element <date>], but not exactly the same.
The date template should always have a parameter called 'when'. The value of this parameter should be a date in the same format as dates in form fields (see above). For example:
<nowiki>{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
Just like form fields, the date can be entered as Julian or Gregorian, and you must use JL or GR to specify which one. This is different from the TEI date element, where @when must always be a Gregorian date in ISO format. TEI dates can also have many other attributes which we don't use here.
To abbreviate the names of days and months, you can add the parameter format=short.
=== Marking up dates in transcribed text ===
In transcripts, summaries or extracts of original sources, you can use the date template to mark up strings that refer to dates.
In this case, the first parameter should contain the original text. This will be displayed as it is. This parameter never has a name.
The value of the parameter 'when' should be the standardized form of the date. You should usually use the same calendar that the original source uses. If it specifies a double Julian and Gregorian date, such as 10/20 October 1642, you can use either calendar, but '''do not''' try to enter both at the same time as it won't work. The standardized date will automatically be displayed as a full date in both Julian and Gregorian calendars, with the day of the week.
For example, if you type this:
:<nowiki>{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL}}
If the day or month isn't known, the parameter 'when' can take incomplete dates in the same way as form fields. In this case, only a partial date will be displayed, in the same calendar that you specified, not a double date, because months and years without days can't easily be converted from one calendar to another.
If the year isn't known, or the date referred to can't be worked out at all, then it's not worth marking up the text as a date.
In 17th-century diaries and letters, it can be common for the day of the week and the number of the day to go out of sync. In these cases, the day of the week can sometimes be more reliable than the date. It's sometimes possible to work out the correct dates by following the sequence to where it went wrong.
When the date template has contents (usually the original text in a transcript) the formatted date will usually be displayed as a footnote. If you need to use a date template inside a footnote, you should add the parameter display=inline to stop the date tag from generating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. In this case, the formatted date will be displayed in square brackets after the original text. For example, if you type this:
:<nowiki>{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL|display=inline}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when Edgehill fight was|when=1642-10-23 JL|display=inline}}
=== Formatting dates in free text ===
In free text other than transcripts of original sources, you can use the <nowiki>{{date}}</nowiki> template as an easy way to format a date with the correct day of the week and equivalent Julian and Gregorian dates.
In this case, the only parameter you always need to use is 'when', which should usually be a full date including year, month, day and calendar. If you don't specify a day, it will only display the partial date in the calendar that you specified, not a double date.
When used like this, the template never creates a footnote, so there is no need to use display=inline. The formatted date will be displayed inline where you type the template.
If you type:
:<nowiki>{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}</nowiki>
it will be displayed as:
:{{date|when=1642-10-23 JL}}
You can also use these optional parameter values to change the format of the date:
* format=short displays the date on one line as usual but abbreviates the names of days and months * format=column splits the date over three lines: ** day of the week spelt in full ** Julian date with abbreviated month ** Gregorian date with abbreviated month
== Displaying dates in query results ==
Query results display one date per column. By default, each date will be displayed in the same calendar that was specified when the date was entered. If you're writing your own query, you can force it to display dates in a certain calendar by appending:
* #JL for the Julian calendar * #GR for the Gregorian calendar
To display double dates, you will need to add a separate column for each calendar and specify the calendar using the codes above.
Note that in query results, Julian dates will be indicated with the suffix JL in superscript, but Gregorian dates won't have any suffix, unlike when they are displayed on the page they were entered on.
You can also change the formatting of dates in query results in other ways, and generate sort keys to sort query results into date order. For more details, see [https://www.semantic-mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Type_Date Semantic MediaWiki help page for dates].
Note that if your query uses a date format that displays the day of the week, Julian dates will have the wrong day because of a bug in Semantic MediaWiki. This does not affect the way that dates are displayed on the pages where they were entered, where the day of the week shown will be correct for both the Julian and Gregorian calendars.
[[Category:Help pages]]

Help pages on this wiki are listed in [[:Category:Help pages]].
This site runs on MediaWiki (like Wikipedia) with Semantic MediaWiki (like Marine Lives). You can get lots of help from the manuals for the software:
* [https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Manual:Contents MediaWiki manual] * [https://www.semantic-mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:User_manual Semantic MediaWiki manual]
[[Project:Known issues|Known issues]] lists problems that we know about but haven't fixed yet.

A wiki page name is an identifier for a page within a wiki. This page may be about a named entity (person, place, organization) but strictly speaking, the page name is an identifier for a resource about that entity, not for the entity itself. Where possible, entities are more rigorously identified by linking to external identifiers.
Page names need to balance these things, which sometimes conflict with each other:
* unique * short * informative
This means that the page name should contain enough information for human readers to be able to find what they're looking for, but no more information than is necessary for that.
A page name '''is not''' a full name history of the entity, and does not always have to show the most correct name for that entity.
== Special characters ==
These characters should not be used in page names:
{| class="swordinfotable" !Character !Reasons |The equals sign has a special meaning in web addresses. It might work in practice, but it's better to avoid it. |- |? |The question mark has a special meaning in web addresses. It might work in practice, but it's better to avoid it. |- |/ |The forward slash can be used in most page names, and is often needed in archival references, but it should be avoided in page names for Agents or Units because it can cause confusion when creating subpages in the Events and Locations namespaces. We now use \ to separate multiple commanders' surnames in the page names for military units. |}
Apart from these, any Latin unicode characters can and should be used to spell names correctly. It's better to transliterate characters from other alphabets into the Latin alphabet. All text added to this site should use UTF-8 character encoding.
== People ==
People can be [[Form:Agent|Agents]] (if they were alive during the British Civil Wars) or [[Form:Author|Authors]] (if they weren't alive at this time and are only included as authors or editors of published texts. Similar naming conventions apply to both.
Surnames should usually come first, followed by a comma, then by forenames and/or initials. The main exception to this rule is for royalty who are commonly known by forenames and either don't have surnames or who are not commonly known by their surname. In this case, the forename comes first, followed by a comma, followed by a royal title. Years of birth and death may be added for disambiguation to compensate for lack of a surname. For example:
* [[Rupert, Prince (1619-1682)]] * [[Charles I, King (1600-1649)]]
For people whose surname comes first, the qualifiers 'junior' or 'senior' may be used if necessary for disambiguation. These come after the forenames, separated by a space, not a comma:
* Balfour, William senior * Balfour, William junior
Further titles (except peerages: see below) may be used after another comma if needed for disambiguation:
* Balfour, William senior, Sir * Balfour, William junior, Major
A military rank may be used directly after surname if the forename is not known:
* Smith, Captain
Any additional disambiguation information usually goes in round brackets after these names.
Years of birth and/or death should only be used if they are absolutely necessary for disambiguation and are certainly known. Often they can be omitted. If they are included, they should be the first thing inside the brackets, before anything else.
Only the most distinctive occupation or other role should be used: the purpose is disambiguation, not to provide a comprehensive description of a person's life.
For modern historians, it's usually only necessary to put 'historian' in brackets. Peerages, knighthoods and other titles can be included. For example:
* [[Russell, Conrad (5th Earl Russell, historian)]] * [[Roy, Ian (historian)]] * [[Hopper, Andrew (historian)]]
It's best if the actual page name uses one or more full forenames unless the historian is much better known by their initials:
* [[Gardiner, S R (historian)]]
But alternative forms with initials can also be redirects. In either case, there are no full points after an initial.
Page names should usually use a person's most well-known name. The original spelling from a historical person's signature is preferred if known, but this won't be enforced rigidly.
The words 'royalist' and 'parliamentarian' should only be used as qualifiers if a person held an actual position in the organization of one side and never for the other, and if these qualifiers are particularly useful for disambiguation or identification of a person.
=== Peers ===
Use surname, forename, and highest/last title held. Year of death can be added to help with disambiguation but in most cases it's not necessary:
* [[Devereux, Robert (3rd Earl of Essex)]] * [[Cavendish, William (1st Duke of Newcastle)]] * [[Compton, Spencer (-1643, 2nd Earl of Northampton)]]
There should be a redirect for every peer with the title first and the name in brackets:
* [[Essex, Earl of, 3rd (Robert Devereux)]]
There can also be redirects for previous or subsidiary titles but only the highest/last main title should be used in an actual page name.
=== Married surnames ===
Some people take a new surname on marriage. This has traditionally applied to women in Britain but men and nonbinary people might also take a new surname on marriage.
We have no strict rule about whether to use maiden or married surnames where all are known. Use whichever seems most widely used or easy to understand, even if inconsistent. In some cases, a historical widow's maiden name might not be known.
Examples:
* [[Cavendish, Margaret (-1673, Duchess of Newcastle)]] uses her married name but was born Margaret Lucas. * [[Howard, Frances (Countess of Essex and Somerset)]] uses her maiden name. Her married names were Devereux and then Carr. * [[Willingham, Anne (nee Eaton)]] uses her married name first but has her maiden name in brackets. * [[Betts, Elizabeath (saddler)]] a widow whose maiden name is currently unknown. * [[Mulligan, Lotte (nee Glow, historian)]] uses her married name first but has her maiden name in brackets.
There can be redirects for other surnames.
If a living historian has a married surname but always uses her maiden name professionally, her married surname should be treated as private and not mentioned anywhere on this site.
=== Transgendered people ===
Living transgendered people's deadnames '''must not''' be mentioned anywhere on this site. They may be mentioned in sources linked to by external identifiers but we can't help that.
== Military units ==
Armies are capitalized and should have as short names as possible. Allegiance can be added after a comma if needed for disambiguation, but can often be left out. Armies can be known by a commander's name, a place name, or both. Sometimes years of existence are needed for disambiguation. Examples:
* [[Essex's Army]] * [[Oxford Army]] * [[Eastern Association Army]] * [[New Model Army]] * [[Army of Covenant (2nd Bishops War)]] * [[Army of Covenant (1643-47)]] * [[Newcastle's Army]]
Units such as regiments, troops and companies were mostly known by the commanding officer's name and did not have official names of their own. In these cases, the page name should have two parts separated by '-'. The first part should be the names of one or more commanding officers. The second part should be the type of unit and any other information needed for disambiguation, such as the army it was in, the side it was on, or the years when it existed.
The first part should put a surname first. If there was only one commanding officer, the forename can be used in the same way as pages for people, but sometimes it can be omitted if the unit or colonel is very well known or there were no similarly named units. If there were multiple commanding officers, multiple surnames can be used, separated by '\' (we no longer use '/' as it can cause confusion when creating subpages in the Events and Locations namespaces). Commanders' names don't have to be in chronological order. It's better to start with the name that seems to be best known or that was used for longest, but this is flexible as cases will vary. Not every commander has to be included in the page name, especially if they only served for a short time. Extra disambiguation information such as ranks, titles or senior/junior can be added if needed.
The second part should start with a unit type, such as 'horse troop' or 'foot regiment'. This is usually in lower case because it's a description, not a proper noun. If the army, allegiance or other parent unit are needed for disambiguation, the can go next after a comma. Army names should be capitalized but regiment names shouldn't. New Model Army units will probably always have 'New Model Army' in the page name, and will be treated as separate units from their predecessors. Any other disambiguation information, such as years active, can go in brackets.
Examples:
* [[Cromwell\Vermuyden\Disbrowe - horse regiment, New Model Army]] * Balfour, William senior, Sir - horse troop, Essex's Army * Balfour, William junior, Major - horse troop, Essex's Army * Cromwell\St John\Cooper - horse troop * Cromwell, Oliver junior - horse troop, Eastern Association * Long, Walter - horse troop (1642) * Long, Walter - horse troop (1643)
There should be a redirect for every commanding officer. These should start with surname then forename like person pages. Names of other commanding officers should be added in brackets only if they are absolutely necessary for disambiguation. For example, these redirect to [[Cromwell\Vermuyden\Disbrowe - horse regiment, New Model Army]]:
* [[Vermuyden, Bartholomew - horse regiment, New Model Army]] * [[Disbrowe, John - horse regiment, New Model Army]]
== Households ==
A unit page that represents a household should usually start with the page name of the head of household followed by '- household'. For example:
* [[Willingham, George (-1651, London merchant) - household]]
== Places ==
Counties of England, Scotland and Wales should usually have the English name used by the [http://www.county-borders.co.uk/ Historic Counties Standard] followed by a comma then the country name:
* [[Essex, England]] * [[Denbighshire, Wales]] * [[East Lothian, Scotland]]
There should be a redirect for:
* alternative English names shown in the Historic Counties Standard * Welsh language names of Welsh counties. Most are shown in the Historic Counties Standard. Some alternatives come from Wikipedia. Country suffix should be ', Cymru'. * Gaelic names of Scottish counties. These are mostly taken from [https://www.ainmean-aite.scot/ Ainmean-Àite na h-Alba]. A few that are not explicitly given there are taken from Wikipedia or other sources. Country suffix should be ', Alba'. * we don't yet have a source for Scots names of Scottish counties where these differ from English names.
Settlements should have name, county at large and country:
* [[Colchester, Essex, England]] * [[Coggeshall, Essex, England]]
Except that county should be omitted if the county name is taken from and very close to a city name. For example, 'Gloucester, England' not 'Gloucester, Gloucestershire, England'.
Places in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire should also be qualified by the name of the riding, even if the page name would be unique without it:
* [[Grimsby, Lindsey, Lincolnshire, England]] * [[Doncaster, West Riding, Yorkshire, England]]
May need further disambiguation if two places have same name in same county.
Spellings of settlement names should usually be the English names used by Ordnance Survey data, unless there is a good reason to use an older name. Hyphens between words are replaced by spaces in page names, for example, 'Stratford upon Avon', not 'Stratford-upon-Avon'. There should be redirects for versions with hyphens. This rule does not apply to English names of settlements in Scotland where the hyphen is used to add a suffix such as -head or -side.
There should be redirects for Welsh and Gaelic names if shown in Ordnance Survey data, or if they can easily be imported from other sources. [This rule may need changing after more detailed examination of OS data.] Welsh Language Commissioner has a [http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.cymru/English/Commissioner/PlaceNames/Pages/Download.aspx CSV file of Welsh places names], linked to OS IDs, available under OGL.
Durham is a special case. Use:
* for the settlement page: [[Durham (settlement), England]] * for the county page: [[Durham (county), England]] * suffix for pages for other places in the county: County Durham, England
Rural parishes should usually be settlement name followed by parish:
* [[Great Missenden parish, Buckinghamshire, England]] * Hawerby cum Beesby parish, Lincolnshire, England
Similarly, subunits should be settlement name + chapelry/township/hamlet/whatever.
But urban parishes should be disambiguated by saint's name:
* St Botolph Aldgate parish, London, England
Parish churches should have pages with same names as parishes but with 'church' instead of 'parish':
* Earls Colne church, Essex, England * St Botolph Aldgate church, London, England
St is usually preferred to Saint as this style is used by Ordnance Survey data for most place names.
But where a parish name combines more than one settlement, it's better to name the church only after the settlement where it actually is (if this is known), not after the whole parish. For example, 'Hawerby church, Lincolnshire, England' not 'Hawerby cum Beesby church, Lincolnshire, England'.
Other buildings should usually have the name of the building and the name of the settlement they are in or near, unless the settlement name already appears in the building name (this often happens with castles). Urban buildings should also have the street if it's known and useful. Oxford and Cambridge colleges should have Address pages to represent the buildings, and these should be qualified with ' buildings' at the end of the page name to disambiguate them from Unit pages that represent the college as an organization.
Boroughs and corporate counties should be separate entities from settlements in them:
* Colchester borough, England * [[Lincoln city, England]] * [[London city, England]]
Separate entities for county and borough jurisdictions:
* Essex commission of the peace, England * [[Essex shrievalty, England]] * Essex lieutenancy, England * [[Essex constituency, England]] * [[Colchester constituency, Essex, England]] * Lincolnshire commission of the peace, England * Lincoln commission of the peace, England
Ecclesiastical units:
* Lincoln diocese, England * Lincoln archdeaconry, England * Dorchester deanery, England * Edinburgh synod, Scotland * Peebles presbytery, Scotland
Names for these are initially taken from Ecton's ''Liber Valorum'' for England and Wales, or ''Fasti Ecclesiae Scoticanae'' for Scotland but can be improved from other sources.
== Events ==
=== Combat events ===
Start with place name, then date and event type in round brackets. For events that took place in one day, use the full date including calendar. Sieges can often just use the year but if the same place was besieged more than once in a year, the date can be expanded as much as is needed for disambiguation. Event type can include battle, skirmish, siege, assault, sally, storming or anything else that seems appropriate. It doesn't have to match the semantic data. The distinction between battles and skirmishes isn't rigid.
* [[Edgehill (1642-10-23 JL, battle)]] * [[Gloucester (1643, siege)]]
=== Meetings ===
Start with the name of the organization that held the meeting, then full date including calendar in round brackets. For example:
* [[Council of War, Essex's Army (1644-06-19 JL)]] * [[House of Commons, Short Parliament (1640-04-13 JL)]] * [[House of Lords, Short Parliament (1640-05-05 JL)]]
== Manuscripts and collections ==
Should start with GLAM name followed by comma. [[The National Archives of the UK (TNA)]] is abbreviated to TNA, but most other GLAMs are not abbreviated:
* TNA, * British Library, * Bodleian Library,
Then full catalogue reference eg for pieces/volumes:
* British Library, Add MS 18980 * TNA, SP 28/131/3 * Bodleian Library, MS Tanner 62
For lower collection levels, individual texts, and sections, include folio numbers where necessary:
* British Library, Add MS 18980, f. 1 * TNA, SP 28/131/3, f. 1 * Bodleian Library, MS Tanner 62, f. 1
If individual documents in a box don't have official item numbers, the page name can have ordinal numbers in brackets. For example:
* TNA, SP 28/151 (2nd item)
In this case, the orderable reference would be 'SP 28/151' and citable reference would be 'SP 28/151 unfol.'.
We may use the same approach where documents don't have folio numbers.
These will all need default sort string setting (this can be done in editing form) otherwise they won't sort in a sensible order. In the sort string, components should be separated by spaces, not commas or slashes. Numbers should be zero filled to the highest number of digits expected in that context.
For example, pieces in [[TNA, SP 28]] can have up to 3 digits, so the sort string for [[TNA, SP 28/4]] is 'TNA SP 28 004'.
== Printed sources ==
If more than one level (work, major edition, minor edition) is combined into the same page, that page should usually use the naming conventions for the highest level it represents.
=== Works ===
Author surnames and short title will usually do. Use - to separate authors from title because commas can be used in title and italics can't be used in a page name.
* Wanklyn and Jones - Military History * Cruso - Military Instructions * Robinson - Horses, People and Parliament
=== Book major editions ===
Usually as work title but qualified by edition (which can be either an ordinal number or the name of an editor) and year of first publication in brackets:
* Wanklyn and Jones - Military History (1st edition, 2005) * Cruso - Military Instructions (1st edition, 1632) * Cruso - Military Instructions (2nd edition, 1644) * Cruso - Military Instructions (Young edition, 1972)
=== Book minor editions ===
If it has an ESTC number, page name should be 'ESTC, ' + number. For example:
* [[ESTC, S121933]]
Otherwise similar to major edition but also qualified by format and year that this minor edition was published (which is not necessarily the year the major edition was first published). Publisher can also be added if different formats were published by different publishers. For example:
* Wanklyn and Jones - Military History (1st edition, hardback, 2005) * Robinson - Horses, People and Parliament (1st edition, Ashgate hardback, 2012) * Robinson - Horses, People and Parliament (1st edition, Routledge paperback, 2017)
=== Book copies ===
Should usually use holding GLAM, and unique identifier from library catalogue:
* British Library, E.69(10)
A version at the Internet Archive can count as a copy in its own right if the identity of the physical copy that it was scanned from is unknown or irrelevant. For 19th-century and later editions, the identity of the copy doesn't usually matter, although there may be exceptional cases where it does.
For Internet Archive copies, use 'Internet Archive, ' followed by the unique ID from the URL:
* [[Internet Archive, diarymarchesroy00librgoog]]
=== Journals/serials ===
Journals use full current names but omit 'The' from start. Redirects can be used to help find journals under old titles, but these should not be used as property values.
Examples:
* [[British Journal for Military History]] * [[War in History]]
Series of monographs should be in the form 'Publisher - Series title'. Redirects can be used if the publisher has changed. The actual page should be under the current publisher.
Example:
* [[Helion - Century of the Soldier]]
=== Articles ===
Journal article version of record:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (journal)
Journal names are usually full but can be abbreviated if the abbreviation is well known or the full title is very long.
Journal article self-archived version:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (repository)
Chapter in collection:
* Author surname ' - ' abbreviated title (abbreviated title of collection)
=== Theses ===
Author's surname - short title (thesis)
For example:
* [[Robinson - Horse Supply (thesis)]]
== Disambiguation pages ==
A new page created as a disambiguation page should always end with ' (disambiguation)'. The rest of the title should be as short as possible.
Pages that are changed to disambiguation pages after they were created as content pages or redirects should keep the same name.
[[Category:Help pages]]

These are the usual conventions for transcribed text used in text versions on pages for manuscript texts and sections, and printed copies. They are designed to stay fairly close to the text of a manuscript but make some silent changes for ease of reading. If the transcription conventions used in a text version differ from these (for example, if the texts have been imported in bulk from another project), this should be stated in the template {{Intro}} (see the next section below for how to use this template). We are now using wiki templates instead of XML tags to mark up features of transcribed text. These templates are often similar to [http://www.tei-c.org/guidelines/p5/ TEI] tags but not exactly the same. Some templates use a MediaWiki extension to process and display custom XML tags, but there is no need to know about this when editing. == Introductory text == When adding a transcript of a source to that source's page, you should use the template {{Intro}} to add the following information: * where the transcript came from and who made it * whether it's a full transcript or a summary or extracts * whether deleted text is included * whether the transcription conventions are different from the standard ones given on this page (which may be true if the transcript was created by another project) The template has one unnamed parameter which can take any text. This text will automatically be formatted with a box around it to set it apart from the transcribed text. When you use the template {{Intro}} before the start of transcribed text, you should also use the template {{End of transcript}} after the end of the transcribed text. This helps to set the transcribed text apart from the rest of the page as it will have a different font and a horizontal line at the end. It also makes it easier for text miners to find transcribed text as it will be contained in this HTML code:
== Spelling, capitalization and punctuation == Original spelling, capitalization and punctuation are usually retained, except for: * ff at the start of a word is transcribed as F (some other projects transcribe it literally as ff but it should never be transcribed as Ff). This is because 17th-century secretary hand usually used a double lower case f to stand for capital F. * u/v is silently modernized. * i/j is silently modernized. In 17th-century manuscripts, u and v were often used interchangeably, and i and j were often used interchangeably (the same is true for the capital letters U/V and I/J). They should be changed to whatever makes most sense rather than being transcribed literally. For example, 'ivstice' should be transcribed as 'justice', 'Iohn' should be transcribed as 'John', 'uintner' should be transcribed as 'vintner'. Roman numerals are not converted to Arabic numerals. They are transcribed literally except that j is converted to i and u to v. The original capitalization is retained. For example, 'viij' is transcribed as 'viii', not 'viij' or '8'. == Indentation and alignment == All transcribed text should usually be aligned to the left. If the text in the original source is indented, centred, justified or right-aligned, this should be ignored. Indents can be created by formatting text as a bulleted list but this should only be done if the text is logically a list. == Abbreviations and expansion == Abbreviations are expanded in square brackets. Superscript in abbreviations is transcribed as normal text. For example: * p[er]mission * his Ma[jes]tie * troop[es] * [th]e Ampersands should be transcribed literally as & == Insertions == The template {{add}} is used to mark up handwritten insertions that appear in the main text of a manuscript. This is similar to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-add.html add]. The added text will be displayed as underlined text in the wiki page. This template has one unnamed parameter which contains the added text. For example, if you type this: :both {{add|horse and man}} are in good case You will get: :both {{add|horse and man}} are in good case For annotations outside the main text, such as marginal notes, use notes instead (see below). == Deletions == Representing deleted text is optional. You should state in the introduction of a transcript whether or not deletions are represented. To represent deleted text, use the template {{del}}. This is similar to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-del.html del] but does not have any attributes. Text marked up with this tag is displayed as struck through text in the wiki page. This template has one unnamed parameter which should contain the deleted text. If you type this: :the {{del|the}} King You will get this: :the {{del|the}} King == Uncertain or illegible text == If text can be read but the reading is not certain, it should be marked up like this: :we were all [?compleat?] in arms This markup has the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-unclear.html unclear] but does not use a template or XML tag. If text is completely missing because of damage to the document, or if it is present but cannot be read at all, use the template {{gap}}. This is equivalent to the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-gap.html gap] but does not have all of the same attributes. In practice, we only use the following parameters: * '''extent''' is human-readable text describing how much text is missing, such as "2 or 3 words" or "1 line" * '''reason''' is human-readable text describing the reason for the gap in the text, such as "illegible" or "manuscript torn" (We do not have any equivalent of @unit or @quantity.) Each gap template will usually be displayed in the wiki page as [...] followed by a footnote giving the extent of and reason for the gap. For example, if you type this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} You will get this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged}} If you need to mark up a gap inside a footnote, for example missing or illegible text in a later annotation, you should add the parameter display=inline to stop the gap template from creating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. When you use this parameter, the reason and extent will be displayed in square brackets instead of a footnote. For example, if you type this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged|display=inline}} You will get this: :listed one bay gelding with a {{gap|extent=half a line|reason=manuscript damaged|display=inline}} == Dates == You can use the template {{date}} to mark up dates in transcribed text. This has the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-date.html date] but @when has a different meaning from the TEI equivalent and it does not use any other attributes to record information about the date. For more information on how to use this tag and how to deal with different calendars, see [[Help:Dates]]. If you need to use this tag inside a footnote, you should add the parameter display=inline to stop the date tag from generating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote inside a footnote. == Named entities == You can use the template {{name}} to mark up text that refers to named entities such as people and places. This has the same meaning as the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-rs.html rs], '''not''' the TEI element [http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-name.html name], which has a more specific meaning. TEI tags can only be used for proper nouns, but our {{name}} template and the TEI tag can also be used for other strings that refer to an entity without being its actual name, for example: * her husband * the Queen * the Lord General * your horseman The first parameter is unnamed and should contain the actual name string used in the transcribed text. The template should also use either one of these named parameters to identity the entity or entities it refers to: * '''key''' takes one or more page names to link to entities that have been positively identified. Each value will create a semantic link using [[Property:Mentions]]. * '''couldbe''' takes one or more page names to link to entities that the tag could refer to but that have not been positively identified. Each value will create a semantic link using [[Property:Possibly mentions]]. In either case, multiple values should be separated by ; just like in form fields. You should never use both of these parameters at the same time. If key and couldbe are both present, couldbe will be ignored. If no possible identities can be suggested, you should leave out both parameters. In this case, there will be a message saying 'Unidentified' to show that the name has been marked up as a name but not identified, and the page will be added to [[:Category:Sources mentioning unidentified names‏‎]]. Examples of correct use of this tag: * Identified as referring to one entity: {{name|the Lord General|key=Devereux, Robert (3rd Earl of Essex)}} * Identified as referring to two entities at the same time: {{name|the two Creetings|key=Creeting St Peter, Suffolk, England;Creeting St Mary, Suffolk, England}} * Could be one or the other: {{name|Richard Blissett|couldbe=Blissett, Richard senior (harness maker);Blissett, Richard junior (harness maker)}} * Completely unidentified: {{name|Mr Smith}} If you need to use this tag inside a footnote, you must use the parameter display=inline to stop the name tag from generating its own footnote, because you can't have a footnote within a footnote. For example: * {{note ms|{{name|Richard Blissett|display=inline|couldbe=Blissett, Richard senior (harness maker);Blissett, Richard junior (harness maker)}} his booke}} == Notes == You can create footnotes with the templates listed below. We don't recommend using tags because there are rare circumstances where XML tags can cause problems, and for the sake of consistency because our current practice is to use wiki templates for all markup. If you need to use {{name}}, {{date}} or {{gap}} templates inside a footnote, they must have the parameter display=inline. Otherwise these tags will generate their own footnotes, which won't work inside a footnote. These templates each have one unnamed parameter. They all work in the same way, but each template is used for a different purpose: * {{note}} is used to create footnotes for citations in free text other than transcripts of sources. This has the same effect as a tag at Wikipedia. We do not use citation templates like Wikipedia because our linked data approach removes the need to repeat all of the citation information every time a source is cited. Citations should usually contain an internal link to a source that is represented by a page on this wiki and/or an external link to a source that has been published on another website. You can combine both to link to an edition represented by a page on this wiki and the relevant page at the Internet Archive. * these templates are used to mark up transcripts of sources. They have a similar meaning to the TEI element [https://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-note.html ], 'marked in some way as being out of the main textual stream': ** {{note ed}} for new editorial notes added in this wiki. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Editorial note'. ** {{note print}} for original footnotes, endnotes or marginal notes printed in an early printed text. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Printed note'. ** {{note ms}} for handwritten notes found in a text. These will automatically be prefixed with 'Manuscript note'. Manuscript notes can be: *** handwritten marginalia in a printed text *** additions to manuscript text 'marked in some way as being out of the main textual stream'.[http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html#CONONO TEI P5 guidelines]. But for contemporary additions or alterations that are part of the main text, use the template {{add}} instead. === Examples === ==== Citation in free text ==== If you type: :Strength in July 1644: 11 officers, 74 troopers{{note|[[Symonds - Diary (Long edition, Camden Old Series 74, 1859)]], [https://archive.org/stream/diarymarchesroy00librgoog#page/n99/mode/2up page 73].}} You will get: :Strength in July 1644: 11 officers, 74 troopers{{note|[[Symonds - Diary (Long edition, Camden Old Series 74, 1859)]], [https://archive.org/stream/diarymarchesroy00librgoog#page/n99/mode/2up page 73].}} ==== Original footnote in printed text ==== If you type: :These forms (in Walhausens opinion) are of {{note print|So the said author conceiveth; but it is very doubtfull.}} speciall advantage You will get: :These forms (in Walhausens opinion) are of {{note print|So the said author conceiveth; but it is very doubtfull.}} speciall advantage ==== Contemporary annotation in manuscript ==== If you type: :Demi-culverins 4, horses to draw them 60{{note ms|12 horses enough}} You will get: :Demi-culverins 4, horses to draw them 60{{note ms|12 horses enough}} ==== Marginalia in printed text ==== If you type: :is perswaded into Cornwal to credit Roberts for getting his Rents{{note ms|This is a base lie}} You will get: :is perswaded into Cornwal to credit Roberts for getting his Rents{{note ms|This is a base lie}} ==== New editorial note ==== If you type: :In the end of this month of May died Mr. John Pym{{note ed|This is an error. Pym died in December 1643.}} You will get: :In the end of this month of May died Mr. John Pym{{note ed|This is an error. Pym died in December 1643.}} == Headings == Wiki markup can be used to represent logical headings in the transcribed text. For example, an account book might have section headings for dates or administrative areas. See [[Wikipedia:Help:Section]] for more information about heading markup. Each text transcript version is under a level 2 heading. This means that headings marked up within the transcript should start at level 3. For example: === 12o Oct[ober] 1643 === == Lists == You can use wiki markup to create bulleted lists for things that are logically lists, even if they don't have bullets in the original text. To create a one-level list, just put * at the start of each line and a single line break at the end of the line. For example, if you type this: 
* Colonel Cromwells troop
* Major Whaleys troop
* Captain Swallows troop
It will be displayed as: * Colonel Cromwells troop * Major Whaleys troop * Captain Swallows troop For more complex lists, you can add extra levels by adding an extra * at the start of the line. For example, if you type this: 
* Colonel Cromwells regiment
** Colonel Cromwells own troop
** Major Whaleys troop
** Captain Swallows troop
* Colonel Fleetwoods regiment
It will be displayed as: * Colonel Cromwells regiment ** Colonel Cromwells own troop ** Major Whaleys troop ** Captain Swallows troop * Colonel Fleetwoods regiment You can create numbered lists by using # instead of * but there are likely to be fewer cases where these are useful. == Tables == Wiki tables can be used to represent layouts that are logically tables, even if the manuscript does not draw lines around the rows and columns. For example, many account books are laid out like tables. See [[Wikipedia:Help:Table]] for the basics of how to mark up tables. == Bold, italic and black letter text == Italic text in transcripts of printed sources should represented by wiki markup for italics, which is two single quote marks before and two after the italic text. For example, if you type this: I shall be made a ''Bishop'', and grow fat It will be displayed as: I shall be made a ''Bishop'', and grow fat Bold text is used to represent black letter type in transcripts of early printed sources. The wiki markup for bold text is three single quote marks before and three after. For example, if you type this: '''It chanced that I carried a young Maid''' It will be displayed as: '''It chanced that I carried a young Maid''' == Page breaks == You can use the template {{pb}} to represent a page break in the transcribed text. This is similar to the TEI element [http://www-old.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-pb.html pb] but has some different attributes. It should not contain any transcribed text and should only use the following named parameters (parameter names can be omitted if the parameter values are in this order): * '''type''' is the type of break. It should always be used if possible and should have one of the following values: ** '''f''' for a folio. This is the usual numbering system in manuscripts, but some may have page numbers. A folio number usually refers to one sheet of paper in a manuscript. The number should be qualified with r for recto (the front of the sheet, which is on the right when viewed in a bound volume) or v for verso (the back of the sheet, which appears on the left when viewed in a bound volume). ** '''p''' for page. This is the usual numbering system in modern printed texts, and is also found in some manuscripts. Some early printed texts use signatures instead. A page number usually refers to one side of the paper. The front and back will have different numbers. ** '''col''' for a column. Some printed books have more than one column on each page, and each column has a unique number. ** '''sig''' for signature, which is sometimes found in early printed texts instead of page numbers. These are usually a capital letter followed by a number, followed by r for recto or v for verso. ** if there is no numbering system at all, you can omit the parameter. In this case the tag will be displayed as "[unnumbered page break]" and will not have an ID that can be linked to. * '''n''' is the number of the folio, page or signature. It should be used if type is "f", "p", "col", or "sig", but can be omitted if there is no numbering system. For folios and signatures, it should be followed by r for recto or v for verso. * '''facs''' contains a URL to link to an image of the page if one is available somewhere else on the web. For example, many printed sources have page scans freely available at the Internet Archive. This is the same as @facs in the TEI pb element. This will currently only work if the page break also has a type and a number. Examples: A folio in a manuscript. If you type this: {{pb|type=f|n=42v}} It will be displayed as: {{pb|type=f|n=42v}} A page in the published diary of Richard Symonds, with a link to the page image at the Internet Archive. If you type this: {{pb|type=p|n=73|facs=https://archive.org/details/diarymarchesroy00librgoog/page/n99}} It will be displayed as: {{pb|type=p|n=73|facs=https://archive.org/details/diarymarchesroy00librgoog/page/n99}} A page break in a text with no numbering system: If you type this: {{pb}} It will be displayed as: {{pb}} == Line breaks == Line breaks in the original text are not usually represented here. Optionally you can represent them in the editing form for ease of proofreading by typing a single line break but this will be ignored when the page is displayed. MediaWiki treats a single line break as a space when displaying the page. [[Category:Help pages]]

[[Category:Default form categories]]

These authors do not currently have a Wikidata ID. This is usually because a Wikidata item doesn't exist for them, although one may have been created since we last checked. Ideally these authors need to be linked to Wikidata, and a new item created for them if necessary, but this might not be straightforward. Some authors in this category can't be positively identified, and some might not have any unambiguous external identifiers that can be used to create a Wikidata item.

It can also include subdivisions of counties and other anomalous areas that had some characteristics of a county. Redirects for alternative English names can be categorized using this category. Kernow is also included for Cornwall, but other Celtic language names are listed in different categories:
* [[:Category:Counties of Scotland by Gaelic name]] * [[:Category:Counties of Wales by Welsh name]]

This is a parent category for subcategories that list open access versions of different kinds of sources. The definition of 'open access' might vary between subcategories but they should all at least be free to view online.
[[Category:Categories]]

Pages in this category represent [[article]]s and contain a link to an open access version of the article. This means that it is available to view online free of charge and with no registration or login required. The online version may be page scans, digital text, or both. Copying and reuse may be restricted.
[[Category:Open access]]

Pages in this category represent books and contain links to open access scans of page images for the whole book. Digital text will not necessarily be available. Open access means that it is available to view online free of charge and with no registration or login required. Copying and reuse may be restricted.
This category should only be used at [[Book (minor edition)|minor edition]] level. The relevant form includes a checkbox to add this category.
[[Category:Open access]]

These sources have links to manuscript page images at other websites. These are at least free to view without logging in, but reuse may be restricted.
[[Category:Open access]]

These sources have transcripts on this site or links to open access transcripts on other sites. Transcripts on other sites are at least free to view, but reuse may be restricted.
This category should only be added at the highest possible level. If a whole volume has transcripts, the category should be added only to the wiki page that represents the whole volume and not to every individual page within that volume.
[[Category:Open access]]

Each page in this category represents a [[thesis]] and contains a link to an open access version of that thesis. This means that it is available to view online free of charge. If it is at [https://ethos.bl.uk/ EThOS] you must register and log in to view it, but other sites should not require registration or login. The online version may be page scans, digital text, or both. Copying and reuse may be restricted.
[[Category:Open access]]
